captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

The small hot hatch market is
all about two cars right now--

the Clio RS, and this, the new
Ford Fiesta ST. The Fiesta is

cheaper, less powerful, less
snazzy, and it has a proper
manual gearbox.

Ford is very good at
these cars, so this
should be pretty special.

Fiesta has been positioned,
quite cleverly, at 16,995

pounds, a few grand
beneath the Clio.

It offers 182 horsepower from
a tweaked version of the

turbocharged 1.6-liter
EcoBoost motor.

But the 215 foot-pounds of
torque is very impressive and

actually shaves the
Clio's figure.

You can see where the
money has been
spent, or rather, saved.

You get a standard Fiesta cabin
with some massive Recaro

seats, a fancy gear nob,
and a decent wheel.
But that's your lot, really.

The cash has been spent on the
lower chassis, some new

suspension components, and
all-around disc brakes.
Oh, and a couple of tailpipes.

The question on everyone's lips,
on Twitter, on YouTube

on PistonHeads is, would you
have the Clio RS, or would you
have the new Fiesta ST?

Well, I'm in the new Fiesta
ST right now.

And I can't give you a
definitive answer right away,

because I need to drive both
of them at the same time.

So I want to tell you about this
little Fiesta, because
it's a cracking little car.

A little turbocharged,
4-cylinder motor, 182

horsepower, 214 foot-pounds of
torque, it's the latter figure

that dominates the driving
experience, I have to say.

You just get this thing anywhere
above 2,500 RPM, and

it really pulls, fee;s
like a fast car.

Ford claims 0 to 62 in
under 7 seconds.

For my money, that
makes it quite
fast for a small hatchback.

But, of course, it's
not that small.
Inside, quite basic.

You get a fancy Recaro seat,
which is massively supportive

and has the fastest bum
warmers in the galaxy.

You get a nice, little
ST-embossed steering wheel,
and you get a nice gear lead.
But the rest is Fiesta.
This is back-to-basics Ford.

They're not spending money on
stuff that's a frippery.

They're spending money
on the chassis.

They're spending money on the
motor, on the performance, and

on the few small things
that you touch.
Does it feel special enough?
Yeah, just about, for me.

But it has got so much
performance.

And it's really quite
nimble as well.
Downsides--
the low speed ride is busy.

Once you get it up and flowing,
and the dampers get a

chance to work, it's got
a nice feel to it.

But I have to say, at low speed,
it's a bit busier than
I thought it would be.

Electric steering is quite
light, and obviously, it

doesn't really give
me much of a
connection to the road surface.

But within a few minutes,
I'm just cutting
apexes as I want them.

So I'll give it the
accuracy count.
I think it's good like that.

Gear change is nice, and
short, and quick.

Congratulations, Ford,
on the three pedals.

I really do think it's
a crucial factor.

In the Clio versus Ford debate,
if you want to be more

involved, personally, I want
to have a manual gearbox.

And sitting here, right
now, that might
just sway it for me.

But I don't want to be
definitive on that, as I said,

until I've driven both
of them together.

One thing I love about hot
hatchbacks is that balance,

performance, and grip is just
so well attuned to public
roads, isn't it?

You feel the acceleration on
the turn when I brake quite

hard, tip it in, and really
enjoy the car through the
turn, without being too silly.

The front of the car is just It
turns beautifully, and most

impressively, coming
out of turns, wow!

You just get the right lock on,
pin the throttle, and it
drags itself out.

The way these guys have got
front axles to work in the

last five years is so
impressive, so impressive.

So all in all, it's another
very good, fast Ford.

I think it's lacking
some of the things
the Clio's got, obviously.

If you want paddles, that's
the way forward.

Because that what Renault
offers and nothing else.

And there are some benefits
to the Clio.

It's a bit quicker, I will give
you that, but not that
much quicker.

I have to say, this has got
so much torque to spare.

And if you want a manual
gearbox, well, you don't have
a choice, do you?
You have to take the Ford.

How do you feel about the
exterior of the car?

I think it's a little
bit disappointing.

I think there's a lot of volume
above the rear wheel.
It looks quite tall.

It doesn't have that kind of
sat-down stance that I quite
want in a hot hatchback.

But once you're behind the
wheel, there's no denying how
effective it is.

I also don't care about the fact
that it's mostly standard

Fiesta in here, because as far
as I'm concerned, the standard
Fiesta is very nice.

And what about the quality
of that gearshift?
Well, it's good.

No point in having a manual
shifter if you don't make
something of it.

It's quite short, very,
very slick.
Gear nob--

could be a bit better,
I suppose.

But who am I to complain about
the design of a gear nob?
Look at my beard.
[CAR ENGINE]

Of course, we needed to go to
a track to see how the ST

responds to some
serious abuse.

Well, the brakes resisted fade
well, grip was good, and you

could tweak the line with
the throttle, all
of which was nice.

But even with the ESP switched
off, the car still tried to

trim the line with small
amounts of breaking.
I think off should mean off.

It doesn't in the ST, but
it does in the Clio.

But anyone who buys one of these
will be thrilled with
the package.

It could look a little
tastier.

But for the money, not much
can compete The ST really

shines on the road despite
the harsh low-speed ride.

It just makes you wonder how
quick it will be when Mountune
get hold of it.
Does it beat the Clio?
Mm, I can't tell you.

We need to do that
test pretty soon.

But for me, right now, it's
currently a dead heat.

comments.author: Christopher Woods

comments.text:
+Avrilcadabra I'll have to ask him nicely ;)

Feel to me like torque vectoring only kicks in when you run out of talent - 
the chassis is really nicely balanced and it encourages you to drive 
enthusiastically. :D

I bought the car ex-demo, a salesman had been using it as his daily drive 
for six months and it had 7500 miles on it. Just under 4 mm of tread left 
on the front. 

I ended up putting new tyres on around 15000 miles, after swapping fronts 
and back when I got the car... I think I munch through them fast ;) the 
fronts were borderline illegal!

I know this ST has a single ratio rack but can't remember what it is. It's 
not a fabulous turning circle, but it's got plenty of movement lock-to-lock 
thanks to arch clearance.

It's electric assist steering so very light, but still pinpoint accurate. 
Chris Harris really tells the truth.
comments.author: Christopher Woods

comments.text:
+Christopher Woods thanks that is some good stuff to know, yes I have the 2 
litre one. It corners so well, it's hard to believe something corners 
better, but I guess torque vectoring must. Does the new ST have a different 
steering rack than the base models? mine does to give high speed accuracy 
but it makes the turning circle pretty average. Torque steer seem fine on 
mine though it has less power, it certainly does like to wander at high 
speeds at full throttle.

You are on second set of tyres already?

mines just going on it's third set (bought 2 khumo ku22's to do highway 
miles on) seems a waste to wear out pirelli's or re002's on the highway. If 
you ever get a chance to drive your colleagues ST I'd love to hear a 
comparison.
comments.author: Avrilcadabra

comments.text:
You got the 2 litre Mondeo engine model? A colleague at work has that, I've 
had a ride in it (no drive yet) and it's a much 'rawer' car, very 
mechanical - I liked it a lot.

I also have the problem where it cuts power if I'm too aggressive letting 
the clutch out. It's really embarrassing because it looks like you almost 
stalled ;-) You have to modulate throttle carefully above 3000 rpm - if you 
keep it pinned, the turbo torque just spins the wheels! Short shifting 
through third gear is best for damp days.

Torque steer is present a small amount on very uneven roads, but only if 
you're really giving it some off the line. I'm very surprised how little 
torque steer there is with this car.

Tramlining with the factory tyres is way more noticeable, the Bridgestone 
sidewalls are so stiff! I currently run Hankook Ventus Evo 2 K120s all 
round and it's a much more supple ride (still jiggly at low speeds, but 
nowhere near as twitchy, still loads of dry and wet grip).

Torque vectoring is AMAZING and has saved me more than once. It doesn't 
feel artificial - the car just pivots really happily around its centre 
point and you quickly go from gentle understeer to nailing the corner in a 
lovely arc.

You can take sharp corners unbelievably quickly, and I'm sure it helps on 
faster corners (e.g. tightly curved exit and entry ramps onto motorways), I 
can do them at least 20 mph faster than I think I should be able to with my 
foot on the gas.

If I know I need to disappear quick off the line, I always hit the Sport 
button. Anything more than 'moderate' departure results in it cutting 
throttle.

It's also easy to make the TC light flash just with an 'enthusiastic' shift 
through first and second gear, you can get a brief bit of wheel chirp even 
in the dry. To be honest I've begun turning Sport on at every set of 
traffic lights just to avoid the engine thinking I'm about to spin the 
wheels, it's way too conservative.
comments.author: Christopher Woods

comments.text:
+Christopher Woods I have the previous model ST, I still have yet to see 
the turbo ST at a dealer here in Aus or I'd have taken one for a drive. I'm 
assuming they have improved the electronics a lot. Mine has no traction 
control so it's often spinning, can be a bit of a nightmare in the wet in 
city driving. Problem being if It spins while cornering it harshly cuts 
power to the engine.

So if you are pulling into a busy road and have to floor it while right 
turning into traffic, it will cut engine power for a second infront of 
oncomming vehicles. So after having the stability control nearly kill me 
several times I turn it off in city driving.Does the new ST's still have 
any of these issues?

Quite curious about the vectoring also, My ST doesn't have it, does the new 
ST have no torque steer because of it?
comments.author: Avrilcadabra

comments.text:
+Avrilcadabra the torque vectoring I guess is always on due to the 
fundamental handling of the car, I personally think Sport mode reduces its 
aggressiveness. Chris specifically talked about ESP, which includes the 
Traction Control feature.

The Ford site published this:

"The Fiesta ST’s advanced technology converts its raw power into a dynamic 
drive – but one that’s always under your control. It has a specially tuned, 
lowered chassis for precision handling; Torque Vectoring Control, a cutting 
edge technology which gives you optimum grip when cornering; and an 
Electronic Stability Programme (ESP), to help you in the most challenging 
road conditions. Depending on how you like to drive, you can choose from 
three different modes in the ESP: ‘On’, ‘Wide slip’ mode (which means no 
traction control), or ‘Off’, with no intervention whatsoever."

I've not yet taken it on a track day to compare all three modes...

comments.text:
I bought one a month ago after having an '05 Mazda 3.  As I'm in the states 
I bought the 3 with the 2.3L normally aspirated motor that I think the UK 
only had in the Mazda 6.  It produced ~160bhp.  Here's what I'll say about 
the Fiesta ST.  As soon as the turbo spins up everything is torque, most 
people that actually test the car say they get around 240lbs/ft.  The car 
only weighs 2700lbs, probably lighter in the UK as you guys get a 3 door 
version.  It's fast, well I don't know if it's FAST, but it feels quick. 
 Every trip to work, every trip to the shop is an event in a good way.  I 
would wish for a factory or dealer installed Monotune package, sadly no 
such luck here in the USA.  I guess the one comment I will say, sort of 
against it is, you have to stay in the boost if you want the car to be 
great, below 2000rpm, it's really quite boring though good on gas.
